prompt.p: A 52-year-old man presents with a 2-year history of excessive sweating, carpal tunnel syndrome and joint pain. He tells you that he can no longer wear his wedding ring and that his shoe size has increased.
Which of the following investigations would you request?

choiceInteraction.simpleChoice: Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) and thyroid function tests (TFTs)

modalFeedback.p: Option A is Correct. GGT and growth hormone measurements confirm excessive growth hormone production and therefore acromegaly.
Option B is Incorrect. TFTs are not useful in diagnosing acromegaly.

Option C is Incorrect. Prolactin secretion is associated with a prolactinoma from the posterior part of the pituitary gland; acromegaly is due to the secretion of growth hormone from the anterior pituitary.
Option D is Incorrect. A random growth hormone is not helpful in diagnosing acromegaly as it may be high in normal people.
Option E is Incorrect. SHBG is used when investigating polycystic ovarian syndrome; it is not useful in diagnosing acromegaly.
